g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
Agroecological approaches: the role of local and indigenous knowledge and
Major improvements in agricultural productivity have been recorded over recent decade
However, progress has also come with social and environmental costs, high levels of greenhouse gas
emissions and rising demand for natural resources
Trend analysis indicate that, of global demand for land, a large share is projected to be supplied by
South America, in particular the Amazon
. In developing countries, land use change for satisfying international meat demand is
leading to deforestation. In Brazil, the amount of GHG emitted only by the beef ca
65% of the emissions of the agricultural sector and 15% of the overall emissions of the country
Agricultural and food systems are complex and diverse; they include traditional food systems, mixed
. Multiple forms of visible and invisible
flows of natural resources exist in global food systems
Technological practices, management and changes in the food chain could help adapt to climate change,
reduce emissions and absorb carbon in the soils, thus contributing to carbon dioxide removal (IPCC,
2018, 2019). A range of technologies can be implemente
d, from highly technological options such as
technologies such as agroecological approaches adapted to local circumstances
. These agroecological approaches are the subject of this box.
For developing countries, agroecological approaches could t
ackle both climate change challenges and
SIDSs, they support livelihoods to develop local
food value chains can promote sustainable management of natural resources, preserve biodiversity and
esilience to climate change impacts and natural disasters
to different social, economic and ecological
integrated with the social and cultural capital of rural territories and local resources
c.), without leading to technological dependencies
ology is a dynamic concept that has gained prominence
three of which will be briefly discussed here: agroecological intensification, agroforestry and biochar
Agricultural intensification provides ways to use land, water and energy resources
food supply while also addressing concerns about climate change and biodiversity
ecological processes and functions in agroecosy
stems. In line with the development of the concept of
agroecology, agroecological intensification integrates social and cultural perspectives
address both employment and food security challenges
Another example of an agroecological approach is agroforestry. Agroforestry provides examples of
in Niger. The practice is based
on the assisted natural regeneration of trees in cultivated fields, an old method which was slowly dying
